div.head: Animals dried in an oven
div.ab: Small cats are skinned and one removes their eyes &all their entrails. One puts a small stick vertically between their teeth to make them open their mouths wide. Then with iron points one attaches their feet to a small board, giving them the fitting attitude & gait. Once thus attached by their feet with small rings of iron wire, one needs to suspend them in the sun with their spines downwards. In this manner they take & d their shape & dry, & the belly tightens & the tail remains high or with the bend that you will have given it. Once a little dry by this means, one turns the head as one wants, securing it with some tool. Then one finishes drying it in an oven after the bread is taken out. Next one places in its eye sockets balls of lead or of wax, painted according to nature. One paints them with well-gummed ink so that they seem to be jet. One gives it a painted tongue, horns, wings & similar fantasies. Thus for rats & all animals.

div.head: For reddening live crayfish which will seem as if boiled
div.ab: Rub them in quite good vinegar, in which there should be a little eau-de-vie and not much, and they can be served as if cooked and will walk.

div.head: Molding a single spider
div.ab: One needs to plant it on the clay slab, as has been said, on a vine leaf, and make there your first cast & once it has set, uncover the spider up to half its legs, then make the second cast.

In order The hairy feet of large spiders, like any animal hair, does not mold well if it is not flattened, having smeared it with wheat oil, which stiffens it & is quickly dry. Hairy things mix with the sand & do not burn well.

div.head: Molding a single vine leaf
div.ab: Plant it with the points of fine iron latten wire & place diagonally on the clay slab, then cast the first mold. Having set, uncover the back reverse & make the second cast, which once set, you can take away the leaf. And you will need to reheat your mold only once, because there will be nothing to burn.
